findings.title: Malicious Miner
findings.description: A Malicious Miner has the ability to front run transactions much more reliably.

findings.title: Malicious Liquidity Provider
findings.description: A large liquidity provider primarily has the advantage when performing rounding attacks. Since rounding errors favor the liquidity provider, someone may temporarily take something like a 95% stake in the liquidity pool, and then attempt to stack rounding issues to drain funds from the liquidity pool.

findings.title: Malicious Exchange Creator
findings.description: An attacker may create an exchange and set it to any ERC20 token they like, which could lead to impersonation attacks or registering a well-known legitimate token but initializing the liquidity pool in such a way that the token can never be used on the platform.

findings.title: Reentrancy Attack
findings.description: If token allows making reentrancy on `transferFrom(address from, address to, uint tokens)` function by someone except the recipient, then all the liquidity funds might be stolen.

findings.title: Frontrunners can skim ~2.5% from every transaction.
findings.description: An attacker can create a similar transaction to a large victim transaction, increasing their gas fees to ensure execution first, and then exit the position immediately, pocketing the difference without exposing themselves to any risk.
